ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Some python and Latex and practical telescope facts.
An overview of the methods employed to take and reduce optical-wavelength astronomical data, some Python, and how to write and evaluate a telescope proposal.
How to process astronomy data and analyze it, basic python coding, processes in astronomy data collection, how to write a telescope proposal, how telescopes work

Knowledge of how telescopes and astronomical observing processes work. Some skills in analysis of astronomical data with Python as well as scientific writing and the process of putting together an astro research proposal.
Reinforced understandings of observational astronomy and research techniques (including the theory), along with programming practice for actual data reduction and analysis.
Knowledge about telescopes/astronomical imaging, spectroscopy, and how to do CCD data reduction
I learned how to reduce astronomical data, and how to write telescope proposals
I learned how to code using python, analyze raw science images, and write a telescope proposal

I learned the basics of how instrumental astrophysics works, particularly the essential techniques and theory behind optical/infrared and radio astronomy. I learned essential Python coding skills for conducting research and data analysis in astronomy. I also developed skills in scientific writing and communication.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lectures are quite good; you learn a lot about how to take and reduce data. However, homeworks are all in Python, and while the course says that it requires no prior knowledge of Python, coding is never taught so you just have to figure it out yourself. If you're a Python beginner, that makes this course really challenging. I think that this course should be two separate courses -- one that teaches Python, and one that teaches all the content we go over in lecture.

Strengths: you learn a lot about what researchers in astrophysics do, and the processes to interpreting data. The skills that you get from this class are very relevant to activities most astrophysics students do in the near future or already participating in.

Weakness: poor structure in teaching, a bit unorganized, and inaccessible to people who are new to astronomy. There were a group of students who did well in the class because they already had been doing astronomy research for a long time, however, those who have never had python experience or were less familiar with astronomy often had to find ways to learn these things on their own. The lectures were often hard to follow because it was easy to drift off.

This class gave a thorough introduction to research methods in astrophysics. However, the course was not very organized, with assignments often unclear and the significance of the material being discussed sometimes uncertain. Lectures could have been more useful and engaging overall.

Strengths: application of programming to the theory described in lectures; final project was a fun experience.

Weaknesses: techniques for assignments needed to be largely self-learned; largely, a review of basic astronomy (even ASTR 255 delved deeper into some of the data reduction + image processing); midterm exam was forgotten about until last few weeks and sprung on last minute (lecture-focused, as opposed to rest of semester spent on figuring out problem sets).

Strengths: Interesting content with applicable skills, prepares you for field research in astrophysics, Arce and Yasmeen (TF) were both super nice. Weaknesses: Concepts on psets were not explained in class so a lot of self-teaching was necessary (especially for python beginners), steep learning curve for those without experience

For much of the class, there was a disconnect between what was happening in class and what we were doing on the psets. It also seemed really difficult if you didn't have a background in python already. With that said, it's a great class in that it actually teaches you the skills you need to do astronomy.
There was little instruction on the skills required to be successful in the coding for this class. However, it dove into the purposes behind the coding we did and the basics of astrophysics very well

Strengths: the material and content of this course was very interesting to me; it serves as a clear overview of the basic methods and data for any type of experimental astrophysics research. I appreciated the opportunities for both learning theory/techniques and applying that theory to experimental data analysis problems through Python coding. I particularly appreciated the telescope proposal project, which gave us experience in writing and evaluating proposals for observing time, essential skills for research astronomy.
Weaknesses: overall, lectures could occasionally be more engaging. Also, the coding skills necessary to complete some of the problem sets often were not really taught in class. If one had research/coding experience the coding was relatively simple. However, for those without Python experience, it was likely quite challenging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's required but isn't great.

If you're an astro major, you have to take this class, and I definitely think it teaches a lot of foundations that are helpful for research (as it's advertised!). If you're not an astro major, there are other courses that will teach you more about astrophysics and less about the technical side of observations which are probably more what you'd be looking for.

This course is definitely important for those who are majoring in astrophysics, however, the learning experience can be a bit difficult depending on your level of prior knowledge of topics in this course. Regardless, this course is required for anyone pursuing a degree in astronomy.

I would recommend this course to students who are very interested in astrophysical research. However, if you are more interested in data analysis and astronomy in general, the class is very technical and mostly focused on methods of astronomical observation. It is also not super engaging if you are not already fascinated by the material.
It's a manageable requirement for the major. Generally, yes; but need some experience with Python.
If you are an astro major or have a strong background in programming/data science, yes. Otherwise, if you want to learn more about astronomy, I would recommend another course.
Its required for the Astro majors, otherwise dont take this course, it is poorly organized and there is little feedback for the work you do.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone interested in astronomy or anyone who wants to learn python.
Probably not because the astrophysics you learn is covered in other courses and the actual telescope proposal felt very rushed

This course is required for astronomy and astrophysics majors. I truly think that the content of the course is essential for anyone interested in pursuing astronomy/astrophysics or doing research in the field. However, the course will likely not be particularly interesting or relevant for those not specifically in the field--there are more theory/physics-based astronomy courses at Yale that can actually teach about space.
